metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: With XML Schemas, one element can substitute another element.
content.html: With XML Schemas, one element can substitute another element.

content.text: Let's say that we have users from two different countries: England and Norway. We would like the ability to let the user choose whether he or she would like to use the Norwegian element names or the English element names in the XML document.
content.html: Let's say that we have users from two different countries: England and Norway. We would like the ability to let the user choose whether he or she would like to use the Norwegian element names or the English element names in the XML document.

content.text: To solve this problem, we could define a substitutionGroup in the XML schema. First, we declare a head element and then we declare the other elements which state that they are substitutable for the head element.
content.html: To solve this problem, we could define a substitutionGroup in the XML schema. First, we declare a head element and then we declare the other elements which state that they are substitutable for the head element.

content.code_html:
<xs:element name="name" type="xs:string"/>
<xs:element name="navn" substitutionGroup="name"/>

content.text: In the example above, the "name" element is the head element and the "navn" element is substitutable for "name".
content.html: In the example above, the "name" element is the head element and the "navn" element is substitutable for "name".

content.text: Look at this fragment of an XML schema:
content.html: Look at this fragment of an XML schema:

content.code:
<xs:element name="name" type="xs:string"/>

<xs:element name="navn" substitutionGroup="name"/>


<xs:complexType name="custinfo">


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element ref="name"/>


</xs:sequence>

</xs:complexType>


<xs:element name="customer" type="custinfo"/>

<xs:element name="kunde" substitutionGroup="customer"/>
content.code_html:
<xs:element name="name" type="xs:string"/>
<xs:element name="navn" substitutionGroup="name"/>

<xs:complexType name="custinfo">
  <xs:sequence>
    <xs:element ref="name"/>
  </xs:sequence>
</xs:complexType>

<xs:element name="customer" type="custinfo"/>
<xs:element name="kunde" substitutionGroup="customer"/>

content.text: A valid XML document (according to the schema above) could look like this:
content.html: A valid XML document (according to the schema above) could look like this:

content.code_html:
<customer>
  <name>John Smith</name>
</customer>

<kunde>
  <navn>John Smith</navn>
</kunde>

content.text: To prevent other elements from substituting with a specified element, use the block attribute:
content.html: To prevent other elements from substituting with a specified element, use the block attribute:

content.code_html: <xs:element name="name" type="xs:string" block="substitution"/>

content.text: Look at this fragment of an XML schema:
content.html: Look at this fragment of an XML schema:

content.code:
<xs:element name="name" type="xs:string" block="substitution"/>

<xs:element name="navn" substitutionGroup="name"/>


<xs:complexType name="custinfo">


<xs:sequence>


<xs:element ref="name"/>


</xs:sequence>

</xs:complexType>


<xs:element name="customer" type="custinfo" block="substitution"/>

<xs:element name="kunde" substitutionGroup="customer"/>
content.code_html:
<xs:element name="name" type="xs:string" block="substitution"/>
<xs:element name="navn" substitutionGroup="name"/>

<xs:complexType name="custinfo">
  <xs:sequence>
    <xs:element ref="name"/>
  </xs:sequence>
</xs:complexType>

<xs:element name="customer" type="custinfo" block="substitution"/>
<xs:element name="kunde" substitutionGroup="customer"/>

content.text: A valid XML document (according to the schema above) looks like this:
content.html: A valid XML document (according to the schema above) looks like this:

content.code_html:
<customer>
  <name>John Smith</name>
</customer>

content.text: BUT THIS IS NO LONGER VALID:

content.code_html:
<kunde>
  <navn>John Smith</navn>
</kunde>

content.text: The type of the substitutable elements must be the same as, or derived from, the type of the head element. If the type of the substitutable element is the same as the type of the head element you will not have to specify the type of the substitutable element.
content.html: The type of the substitutable elements must be the same as, or derived from, the type of the head element. If the type of the substitutable element is the same as the type of the head element you will not have to specify the type of the substitutable element.

content.text: Note that all elements in the substitutionGroup (the head element and the substitutable elements) must be declared as global elements, otherwise it will not work!
content.html: Note that all elements in the substitutionGroup (the head element and the substitutable elements) must be declared as global elements, otherwise it will not work!

content.text: Global elements are elements that are immediate children of the "schema" element! Local elements are elements nested within other elements.
content.html: Global elements are elements that are immediate children of the "schema" element! Local elements are elements nested within other elements.
